title: Portrait exhibit in Gananoque, Ont., depicts cross-section of Canadian life
text:
Portrait exhibit in Gananoque, Ont., depicts cross-section of Canadian life By The Canadian Press October 6, 2015 Helene Beland of Pierreville, Que., is a finalist in this year's Kingston Prize with "Woodland Fairy." Photograph by: The Canadian Press/ , HO-Kingston Prize 
GANANOQUE, Ont. — The 30 finalists in this year’s Kingston Prize for portrait painting will be exhibited at the Firehall Theatre in Gananoque, Ont., from Oct. 9 to 25. 
The touring exhibition serves as “a fascinating snapshot of a cross-section of Canadian life,” say organizers of the prize, which has been awarded every second year since 2005. 
The competition is open to any Canadian artist who depicts a Canadian citizen or landed immigrant in a portrait “based on a real-life encounter,” according to the rules. 
The 2015 finalists include portrayals of tuque-wearing harpsichordist Colin Tilney by Joe Coffey of Victoria; a heavily tattooed lesbian, “Lorraine,” by Jeannette Sirois of Salt Spring Island, B.C.; a woman painted as a “woodland fairy” by Helene Beland of Pierreville, Que.; and a self-portrait by Jessie Babin of Dalhousie, N.B., that takes “Alice in Wonderland” and the stories of Beatrix Potter as starting points. 
The winner of the $20,000 prize, funded by the W. Garfield Weston Foundation, will be announced Nov. 14 at the Beaverbrook Art Gallery in Fredericton. 
As well, the first five Kingston Prize-winning paintings — by artists Mike Bayne, Joshua Choi, Richard Davis, Marcia Perkins and Andrew Valko — are on display at the Agnes Etherington Art Centre in Kingston, Ont., until Dec. 6.
